description:
Subaru Sumeragi is the 13th head of the Sumeragi Clan and a most powerful onmyouji. Subaru is hired to exorcise a construction site, but his employer mysteriously died. The only suspect is a man who repeatedly walks away from situations in which he should have died. Then Subaru meets a young woman intent upon cursing the man, saying that he killed her brother. Subaru must figure out how his employer died and fight the evil spirits that are protecting the man with the help of his friend and twin sister, Seishirou Sakurazuka and Hokuto Sumeragi.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Magic
tags.description: Prominently features magical elements or the use of magic.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Detective
tags.description: Features a character who investigates and solves crimes.

tags.name: Shoujo
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult females.

tags.name: Revenge
tags.description: Prominently features a character who aims to exact punishment in a resentful or vindictive manner.

tags.name: Police
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of law enforcement officers.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Twins
tags.description: Prominently features two or more siblings that were born at one birth.

tags.name: Age Gap
tags.description: Prominently features romantic relations between people with a significant age difference.

tags.name: Yandere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is obsessively in love with another, to the point of acting deranged or violent.

tags.name: Boys' Love
tags.description: Prominently features romance between two males, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Exorcism
tags.description: Involving religious methods of vanquishing youkai, demons, or other supernatural entities.

node.description: [Website](http://www.clamp-net.com) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/CLAMP_news) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/clamp_4_official/) CLAMP is an all-female Japanese manga artist group that formed in the mid-1980s. It consists of leader [Nanase Ohkawa](https://anilist.co/staff/97292), and three artists who shift roles for each series: [Mokona](https://anilist.co/staff/100802) (もこな), [Tsubaki Nekoi](https://anilist.co/staff/100804), and Satsuki Igarashi (いがらし寒月). Almost 100 million CLAMP tankōbon copies have been sold worldwide as of October 2007. In general, Ohkawa gets her inspiration for the group from everyday events such as dreams or the news. Unlike most manga artists who specialize in a single genre, CLAMP has created a diverse body of work. CLAMP's genres vary widely, from childish and comedic (Cardcaptor Sakura, Clamp School Detectives) to more dramatic and teen-rated (xxxHolic, X) series. Furthermore, drawing from the idea of Osamu Tezuka's Star System as they did in Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, CLAMP often crossover characters from their own series into their other works, which gives rise to a loosely defined "Clamp Universe".

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉成曜) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoh_Yoshinari) | [Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=yoh_yoshinari)

A Japanese animator, director and storyboard artist currently working at [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/). Yoshinari entered the anime industry through the influence of his older brother, [Kou Yoshinari](https://anilist.co/staff/102136/). Several of his early works were uncredited second key animation and in-betweens for his brother during high school. After leaving professional school, he applied to [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/) and [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/). Not receiving a response from Gainax, he joined Madhouse. Due to a misunderstanding, Gainax failed to process his application until three months later. Not wanting to explain, Yoshinari told Madhouse; "being an animator is too hard for me," and switched to Gainax.

At Gainax, Yoshinari had joined just after the closure of [Nadia: The Secret of Blue Water](https://anilist.co/anime/1251/). With nothing to do, he was immediately put onto visual development for the film [Aoki Uru](https://anilist.co/anime/21430/), although the film’s production was later broken off due to the studio’s financial state. Undoubtedly his breakout as an animator was just a few years later when he served as one of the lead animators in [Neon Genesis Evangelion](https://anilist.co/anime/30/). Yoshinari worked at Gainax until leaving for Trigger in 2011, a studio founded by fellow ex-Gainax members, [Hiroyuki Imaishi](https://anilist.co/staff/97349/) and [Masahiko Ootsuka](https://anilist.co/staff/108023/). At Trigger he debuted as a director on [Little Witch Academia](https://anilist.co/anime/14349/).

Yoshinari is recognized by the way he represents volume and perspective using spheres, especially for smoke and explosions, as well as his character action in general. His characters often borrow traits from western animation, such as rectangular heads, low contrast shading, big eyes and angular lineart. He uses expertly timed smears, dramatic camerawork, and complicated background animation to convey dynamism. His movement is springy and tense, cleanly situated in the dominant cartoony style of ‘00s Gainax. He remarks [Nijitte Monogatari](https://anilist.co/manga/112385/) as one of his most important influences, with his artistic style particularly visible in his design work for [Tengen Toppa Gurren Lagann](https://anilist.co/anime/2001/) and Little Witch Academia.

Also a big fan of [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)’s, having done multiple short [animations](https://anilist.co/anime/123638/) based on his manga characters.

Married to producer [Naoko Tsutsumi](https://anilist.co/staff/150017/).

(Sources: Wikipedia, Anidb, Animators Wiki)
Handles special effects.

Noted for her work as a character designer and animation director on numerous anime series.

Learned the ropes studying under [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/). After working as an animator at Kugatsusha, an animation studio led by Yasuhiko, she moved to [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) and provided the character designs for titles such as [Tokyo Babylon](https://anilist.co/anime/1043/), [DNA²](https://anilist.co/anime/563/), [Tetsuwan Birdy](https://anilist.co/anime/566/) as well as the extremely well received mahou shoujo series, [Cardcaptor Sakura](https://anilist.co/anime/232/).

Soon after this Takahashi left Madhouse and teamed up on [Shuukou Murase](https://anilist.co/staff/100793/)'s directorial debut, [Witch Hunter Robin](https://anilist.co/anime/7/) - once again handling the role of character designer. In 2006, she designed the characters for [Ouran High School Host Club](https://anilist.co/anime/853/).

Since then Takahashi has been working exclusively on shows made by either [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) or [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).

Noted for her work as a character designer and animation director on numerous anime series.

Learned the ropes studying under [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/). After working as an animator at Kugatsusha, an animation studio led by Yasuhiko, she moved to [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) and provided the character designs for titles such as [Tokyo Babylon](https://anilist.co/anime/1043/), [DNA²](https://anilist.co/anime/563/), [Tetsuwan Birdy](https://anilist.co/anime/566/) as well as the extremely well received mahou shoujo series, [Cardcaptor Sakura](https://anilist.co/anime/232/).

Soon after this Takahashi left Madhouse and teamed up on [Shuukou Murase](https://anilist.co/staff/100793/)'s directorial debut, [Witch Hunter Robin](https://anilist.co/anime/7/) - once again handling the role of character designer. In 2006, she designed the characters for [Ouran High School Host Club](https://anilist.co/anime/853/).

Since then Takahashi has been working exclusively on shows made by either [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) or [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).
__[Twitter](https://twitter.com/bbkoichi21)__

Originating from Oh! Production. Former key member at [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/).

More recently he has been working on [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/)'s productions.
Originating from Ad Cosmo.
Originating from Ad Cosmo.
Founder of Studio Homare.

Originating from [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/). Directs on rare occasions.

Worked for Square Enix in Honolulu, Hawaii together with [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/) and others for the first decade of the 2000s and was completely absent from the anime industry because of this. Returned in 2011 and has been active since.
Originating from [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/). He is a member of the Writers Guild of Japan.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/136171134)

A long-serving anime producer, as well as a founder of [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/), [Mappa](https://anilist.co/studio/569/) and [Studio M2](https://anilist.co/studio/6137/). He currently serves as the Chairman of the Board at [Mappa](https://anilist.co/studio/569/).

Maruyama graduated from Hosei University in 1963, and soon after, he found work at [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) in 1965. It was here that he met many of Madhouse's future staff members. In October 1972, he left Mushi Production together with [Rintarou](https://anilist.co/staff/102305/), [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Yoshiaki Kawajiri](https://anilist.co/staff/100812/) and founded Madhouse. From that time onward, Maruyama focused mainly on producing and planning Madhouse's upcoming projects. He also served as the studio's president through the '80s and '90s.

Thanks in large part to his frequent attendance at anime conventions, he has become well-known in America among Madhouse's fanbase. Not simply wanting to emulate past successes, Maruyama frequently says at these events that his goal as a producer is to seek out new challenges that will allow the production staff to keep experimenting. This attitude in part has been the reason why he has encouraged the studio to take on projects that may not seem like sure-fire commercial hits. In addition, Maruyama has long been a supporter of bringing new talents into the animation business, and continues to encourage young people to work in anime.

In 2011, he left Madhouse and founded Mappa. Later in 2016, he left Mappa and founded Studio M2.

(Source: Wikipedia)
Appeared in Star Wars: A New Hope as Commander Praji

__Skills & Abilities:__ Speaks fluent Japanese

Founder, Owner, and Managing Director of Central Park Media.
Co-founder of Manga Entertainment

Katsumi Itou is a sound effects creator. He is also the founder and the representative director of Swara Production and Three S Studio. Prior to creating Swara Pro, he worked at Ishida Sound Production (now Fizz Sound Creation).

(Source: AniDB)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/MoonRed0831) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/有里紅良)

Studied film editing under [Harutoshi Ogata](https://anilist.co/staff/149439/).
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/神保大介)
He ran an editing studio called Ogata Henshuushitsu from 1996 to 2001.
